fullProgramDescription: The Environmental Systems Engineering (ENVSE) undergraduate major provides a foundation in the engineering sciences and earth systems to understand and manage complex environmental systems. The program focuses on developing skills in problem-solving, data analysis, and technology applications, preparing students for careers in engineering, research, policy, and management related to environmental challenges.
shortProgramDescription: Stanford's Environmental Systems Engineering B.S. program combines engineering principles with earth sciences to address complex environmental challenges.
classHighlights: Foundational courses: Students start with foundational courses in engineering, such as Introduction to Environmental Systems Engineering (ENVSE 101), and build on them with courses like Environmental Systems Engineering Design (ENVSE 102/103).
Mathematics and computing: ENVSE students are required to take Calculus (MATH 19-21), Probability and Statistics (STAT 116), and Programming Abstractions (CS 106A/B).
Environmental and earth sciences: Courses include Environmental Systems (EARTH 121), Hydrology (EARTH 122/223), and Environmental Fluid Mechanics (ENVSE 147/247).
Engineering and technology: Students learn about water quality (ENVSE 141/241), air quality (ENVSE 143/243), and energy systems (ENVSE 145/245).

Design and capstone experiences: Students apply their skills in design courses, culminating in a capstone project that integrates their knowledge and skills to address real-world environmental challenges.
Electives and specializations: ENVSE students can choose from various electives, allowing them to specialize in areas like water resources, energy, or climate change.
learningOutcomes: Apply engineering principles to understand and manage complex environmental systems.
Analyze data and develop models to predict environmental phenomena.
Design and implement solutions to environmental challenges.
Communicate complex information effectively to diverse stakeholders.
Work collaboratively in interdisciplinary teams to address environmental issues.
Understand the ethical, social, and policy implications of environmental engineering decisions.
additionalInformation: The major is offered through the Department of Earth System Science and the School of Engineering. Students are encouraged to participate in research and internships to gain practical experience.
